title: Memoir of George Wilson ...
author: Wilson, Jessie A.
snippet: While all move slowly on, four abreast, through the picturesque portion of Princes Street yet to be traversed, and while the crowd thickens on every point of eminence, let us proceed to the Old Calton burial-ground and await its arrival. What is now a level road, Waterloo Place, once looked down on a valley, with a cemetery and the Calton Hill beyond it. In 1 8 1 5 a bridge was made to span the gulf, while the road was carried (painful necessity) though the cemetery, of which a portion now lies on each side of the road.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: Burns' Monument is on Regent Street, and to the right, Regent Terrace, a long row of fine cut-stone residences, with tastefully arranged gardens in front. The ascent to Waterloo Place is quite long and steep. I take the road, which winds up the hill, past the Observatory7 on the one hand, and the monument to Dugald Stewart on the other.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: I now descend to Waterloo Place, past the Post Office, to Princess Street, cross Waverley Bridge, and arrive at my hotel—the Cockburn—about 4.30. That I was more than a little weary may be taken for granted.

title: The cage /
author: Begbie, Harold
snippet: He took a tram at Waterloo Place, and travelled to Leith. His way ran through an apparently interminable mean street of small houses, whose shuttered windows were rimmed with light, and whose roofs were white with snow.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: My own land, nearly four thousand miles away, was to make itself felt and remembered, even amid the notaole in Old World art and nature. I was descending the hill, past that spot on the Southern side, between the London Road and Waterloo Place, where the noble pile of the Royal High-School now marks the site once occupied by the Kirk of Fieid (or Church in the Fields) in which Queen Mary's worthless husband, Darnley, was blown up and murdered in February, 1567 ;—past the handsome little Burns Monument, a pillared Grecian temple on base, with winged griffins supporting an hour-glass ;—past the Prison of Edinboro', embattled with more than forty turrets, and notably handsome (to those who only see it from the outside .')—when I saw something fluttering up the flagstaff Jo. the Royal Hotel, down Prince's Street, and recognized, for the first time in weeks, the starry flag which had so lately been raised anew over the last strong-hold of rebellion !

title: Lucy, Francis and Cousin Bill. A novel, etc
author: Wistan, Aden.
snippet: She waited till the sound of the footsteps died in the distance, and then ventured out. She looked in eveiy direction, but saw no one she recognized, and then walked on along George Street to the Post Office in Waterloo Place.

title: Scottish Ghost Stories
author: O'Donnell, Elliott
snippet: Lady Adela, used as she was to the privacy of her yacht, and the freedom of her big country mansion, where all sounds were regulated at her will, chafed at the near proximity of her present habitation to the noisy thoroughfare, and vaguely looked forward to the hours when shops and theatres were closed, and all screeching, harsh-voiced products of the gutter were in bed. To her the nights in Waterloo Place were all too short; the days too long, too long for anything. The heavy, lumbering steps of a policeman at last broke her reverie.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: On our way through Waterloo Place to Princess Street we pass the new Post Office and Register Office. In front of the latter is a fine equestrian statue of the Duke of Wellington.
